member.remarks: The device triggers when the signal passes through the threshold you specify with the property, has the slope you specify with the property, and passes through the hysteresis window that you specify with this attribute. member.summary: Specifies a list of steps to skip during the reset process.

member.summary: No step is omitted during reset.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaResetStepsToOmit.Routes
member.summary: Omits the routing reset step. Routing is preserved after a reset. However, routing related properties are reset to default, and routing is released if the default properties are committed after a reset.

remarks.note: This enum value is not supported in external calibration or alignment sessions.
This enum value is not supported for the NI 5600/5661.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.Reset
member.summary: Resets all properties to default values and stops export of all external signals and events.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.ResetDevice
member.summary: Performs a hard reset on the device.
member.remarks:
A hard reset consists of the following actions:
Signal acquisition is stopped.
All routes are released.
External bidirectional terminals are tri-stated.
FPGAs are reset.
Hardware is configured to its default state.
All session properties are reset to their default states. During a device reset, routes of signals between the current and other devices are released, regardless of which device created the route. For example, a trigger signal exported to a PXI trigger line that is used by another device is no longer exported. On the NI 5600, if you are using PXI_CLK10, you continue to drive the clock even after a device reset.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.PerformThermalCorrection
member.summary: Corrects the temperature variations that occur while acquiring the same signal for an extended period of time in a continuous acquisition.
member.remarks:
NI-RFSA internally acquires the temperature every time you initiate an acquisition. If you are performing a continuous acquisition, National Instruments recommends calling this method once every 10 minutes in a stable temperature environment to periodically update temperature calibration. If the ambient temperature varies, call this method more frequently.
You cannot call this method if your device is operating in RF list mode.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.summary: Returns the requested response type, based on the current NI-RFSA settings.
member.param: Specifies the IF, RF, or combined (IF and RF) response of the downconverter or RF vector signal analyzer (VSA) that NI-RFSA returns.
Specifies an array containing the frequencies, in hertz (Hz), that correspond to the response data.
Specifies an array containing the magnitude of the requested response, in decibels (dB). The magnitude response is normalized to the center frequency at each frequency in the array.
Specifies an array containing the phase of the requested response, in degrees. The phase response is normalized to the center frequency at each frequency entry in the array.

member.summary: Enables or disables the Soft Front Panel (SFP) session access for the instrument specified by this NIRfsa session.

SFP session access allows the NI-RFSA SFP to access a device with an existing open session and can help you debug your code.
For more information about SFP session access, refer to the Configuring SFP Session Access in LabWindows/CVI or C topic in the NI RF Vector Signal Analyzers Help. Supported Devices: NI 5600/5601/5603/5605/5606 (external digitizer mode), NI 5644R/5645R/5646R, NI 5661/5663/5663E/5665/5667/5668R, NI 5693/5694

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.GetScalingCoefficients
member.summary: Returns coefficients that can be used to convert unscaled data to scaled I/Q data.
member.returns: Returns an object of type .
member.remarks: Acquired data may be unscaled when sent by a peer-to-peer stream or fetched as unscaled data. Use this method to obtain structures in the array that provides gain and offset values you can use to scale this data into the actual I/Q values. The coefficientInfo array returns one element for each channel specified in the channelList parameter. The element order matches the order specified by the channelList parameter. To get the actual I/Q values, scale the unscaled data from an acquisition by multiplying it by the gain value of the appropriate coefficientInfo element, and then add the offset from the same element. The coefficients are calculated by NI-RFSA for the current configuration of the device, so they are only valid for acquisitions obtained with the same device configuration. This method returns the required size in the numberOfCoefficientSets parameter.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.GetTerminalName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the fully qualified name of the signal being queried. Signals can be triggers, clocks, or events. You can pass the terminalName parameter that is returned to the source parameter of a configure trigger function. Supported Devices: NI 5663/5663E/5665
member.param:
Specifies the signal for which you want to query the terminal.
702 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Reference trigger.
1100 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Start trigger.
1102 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Advance trigger.
1200 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Ready for Start event.
1201 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Ready for Reference event.
1202 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Ready for Advance event.
1203 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the End of Record event.
1204 : NI-RFSA returns the terminal name for the Done event.
1205 : NI-RFSA does not support this option for the niRFSA_GetTerminalName function.
member.returns: Returns the fully qualified name of the signal being queried. Signals can be triggers, clocks, or events.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaDriverUtility.ResetWithOptions(NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaResetStepsToOmit)
member.summary: Resets all properties to default values and specifies steps to omit during the reset process, such as signal routes.

remarks.para: For the NI 5600, this method does not reset the PXI Clock signal that is driven by devices installed in the Star Trigger Controller Slot, also known as the System Timing Slot.

By default, this method resets all properties to their default values, aborts generation, clears all routes, and resets session properties to initial values. You can specify steps to omit using the steps to omit parameter. For example, if you specify for the steps to omit parameter, this method does not release signal routes during the reset process.
When routes of signals between two devices are released, they are released regardless of which device created the route.

member.param: Specifies a list of steps to skip during the reset process. The default value is , which specifies that no step is omitted during reset.
member.value: if no step is omitted during reset; if omits the routing reset step.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.summary: Diables the notch filter.

member.summary: Enables the notch filter automatically when it is in the signal path, and disables the notch filter automatically when it is not in the signal path.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNotchFilterEnabled.Enabled
member.summary: Enables the notch filter. If the notch filter is not in the signal path or if the notch filter is not supported on the device, NI-RFSA returns an error. Select whenever possible to avoid an error.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaOspDelayEnabled
member.summary: Specifies whether the digitizer onboard signal processing (OSP) block delays the Reference triggers and the data samples moving through the OSP block, or if the Reference triggers bypass the OSP block and are processed immediately.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaOspDelayEnabled.Disabled
member.summary: The Reference triggers bypass the OSP block and are processed immediately.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaOspDelayEnabled.Enabled
member.summary: The Reference triggers, along with the data samples, are delayed through the digitizer OSP block.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaPreselectorEnabled

member.summary: Disables the preselector.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaPreselectorEnabled.EnabledWhenInSignalPath
member.summary: The preselector will be automatically enabled when it is in the signal path and will be automatically disabled when it is out of the signal path.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaPreselectorEnabled.Enabled
member.summary: Enables the preselector. If the preselector is not in a signal path or if the preselector is not supported on the device, NI-RFSA returns an error. Select the whenever possible to avoid an error.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTrigger.MinimumQuietTime
member.summary: Gets or sets the time duration, in seconds, for which the signal must be quiet before the device arms the trigger.
member.value: By default this value is set to 0, which means the device does not wait for a quiet time before arming the trigger.
member.remarks: The signal is quiet when it is below the trigger level if the trigger slope, specified by the property, is set to or when it is above the trigger level the trigger level if the trigger slope is set to . This property is useful to trigger the acquisition on signals containing repeated bursts, but for which each burst may have large changes in signal power within itself. By configuring the minimum quiet time to the time between bursts, you can ensure that the trigger occurs at the beginning of a burst rather than in signal power change within a burst.
member.exception:
The property was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps
member.summary: Specifies the various steps involved in self calibration of NI-RFSA.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.None
member.summary: No step is involved in self calibration of NI-RFSA.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.PreselectorAlignment
member.summary: The Preselector alignment step generates coefficients to align the preselector across the frequency range of 3.6 GHz to 14 GHz.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.PreSelectorAlignment
member.summary: The Preselector alignment step generates coefficients to align the preselector across the frequency range of 3.6 GHz to 14 GHz.
member.remarks: Use instead of this enumeration constant.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.GainReference
member.summary: The gain reference step measures the changes in gain since the last external calibration was run.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.IFFlatness
member.summary: The IF flatness step measures the IF response of the entire system for each of the supported IF filters.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.DigitizerSelfCalibration
member.summary: The digitizer self calibration step calls for digitizer self-calibration, if the digitizer is associated with the RF downconverter.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.LOSelfCalibration
member.summary: The LO self calibration step calls for LO self-calibration, if the LO source module is associated with the RF downconverter.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.AmplitudeAccuracy
member.summary: Omits the Amplitude Accuracy step. If you omit this step, the absolute accuracy of the device is not adjusted.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.ResidualLOPower
member.summary: Omits the Residual LO Power step. If you omit this step, the Residual LO Power performance is not adjusted.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.ImageSuppression
member.summary: Omits the Image Suppression step. If you omit this step, the Residual Sideband Image performance is not adjusted.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.SynthesizerAlignment
member.summary: Omits the Synthesizer Alignment step. If you omit this step and the method indicates that the calibration data for this step is invalid, the synthesize alignment specifications are not guaranteed.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSelfCalibrationSteps.DCOffset
member.summary: Omits the DC Offset step. If you omit this step and the method indicates the calibration data for this step is invalid, the DC offset specifications are not guaranteed.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa
member.summary: Defines a root class that is used to identify and control the instrument session.
member.remarks: All properties, methods, and events fall under either the NIRfsa class or are the sub-objects of this class. To interact with the NI-RFSA, you must create an instance of this class.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new instrument driver session.
member.param: Specifies the name of the device in which the session is opened.
Specifies whether you want NI-RFSA to perform an ID query. if NI-RFSA performs an ID query; otherwise .
Specifies whether you want to reset NI-RFSA device during the initialization procedure. if the device is reset; otherwise .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instrument driver session and sets the initial state of session properties.
member.param: Specifies the name of the device in which the session is opened.
Specifies whether you want NI-RFSA to perform an ID query. if NI-RFSA performs an ID query; otherwise .
Specifies whether you want to reset NI-RFSA during the initialization procedure. if the device is reset; otherwise .
Sets the initial state of the following session properties: , , , .
member.para: For more information on the format of optionString, refer to the NI RF Vector Analyzer Help.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Ivi.Driver.LockType,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instrument driver session.
member.param: Specifies the resource name of the device to initialize.

Specifies whether NI-RFSA performs an ID query. When you perform an ID query, NI-RFSA verifies the device you initialize is supported. If this parameter is set to , this method queries the instrument ID and checks that it is valid for this instrument driver.

Specifies whether the NI-RFSA device is reset during the initialization procedure. If this parameter is set to , this method resets the instrument to a known state. Sends initialization commands to set the instrument to the state necessary for the operation of the instrument driver.
Specifies the type of lock to create. Note that the actual type created can differ.
Specifies a user-specified access key.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.#ctor(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,Ivi.Driver.LockType,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new instrument driver session.
member.param: Specifies the resource name of the device to initialize.

Specifies whether NI-RFSA performs an ID query. When you perform an ID query, NI-RFSA verifies the device you initialize is supported. If this parameter is set to , this method queries the instrument ID and checks that it is valid for this instrument driver.

Specifies whether the NI-RFSA device is reset during the initialization procedure. If this parameter is set to , this method resets the instrument to a known state. Sends initialization commands to set the instrument to the state necessary for the operation of the instrument driver.
Specifies the type of lock to create. Note that the actual type created can differ.
Specifies a user-specified access key.
Sets the initial state of the following session properties: , , , .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.Ivi#Driver#IIviDriver#Close
member.summary: Closes the session to the device.
member.remarks: The method can be called safely more than once, even if the session is already closed.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.NIRfsa.Dispose
member.summary: Closes the specified session and deallocates the reserved resources, if not already disposed.
member.remarks:
You can call this method safely more than once, even if the session is already closed.
A call to this method disposes the SafeHandle class used to hold the instrument handle. If the call to this method fails due to some reason, like the session being closed by some external means, you will not be notified about the failure. To help you identify failures in the ReleaseHandle method of the SafeHandle class, managed debugging assistant (MDA) is activated.
For details refer to .
The call to this method fails when you externally close a session by:
Initializing a session with a resource name for which the session is already open, within the same process. This causes the instrument handle held by the existing session to become invalid.
Getting the instrument handle out using the method and closing this handle directly.

member.value: if the session is disposed; otherwise, .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaVertical.MixerLevelOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of dB by which to adjust the device mixer level which specifies device settings that are the best compromise between distortion and noise.
member.value: Returns a representing the number of dB by which to adjust the device mixer level. The default value is 0.
member.remarks: Specifying a positive value for this property configures the device for moderate distortion and low noise, and specifying a negative value results in low distortion and higher noise. You cannot set the and property at the same time.

member.value: Specifies a representing the number of dB by which to adjust the default IF output power level. The default value for the offset is 0 dB, which results in an IF OUT output power level of -6 dBm.

member.summary: Gets or sets whether to enable or disable digital equalization filter for the RF downconverter.
member.value: if the digital equalization filter for the RF downconverter is enabled; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Digital IF Equalization is only supported with a 150 MHz clock. You cannot set this property to if the property is set to .

The NI 5665 enables digital IF equalization by default if you set the to . If you set to , digital IF equalization is enabled for instantaneous bandwidths larger than 300 kHz. You cannot perform digital IF equalization for instantaneous bandwidths less than or equal to 300 kHz.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQAcquisition.Initiate
member.summary: Commits settings to hardware, waits for hardware settling, and starts an acquisition.
member.remarks:
You can use this method in conjunction with one of the NIRfsa fetch I/Q methods to retrieve acquired I/Q data, or you can use the or or or
methods to both initiate the acquisition and retrieve I/Q data at one time.
When in the external digitizer mode, this method commits settings and waits for settling, but it does not start an acquisition. Notice that using the method on its own does not wait for hardware settling.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

Specifies the time, in seconds, allotted for the method to complete before returning a timeout error. A value of specifies that the method waits until all data is available. A value of 0 specifies that the method immediately returns available data.

member.remarks: A fetch transfers acquired waveform data from device memory to computer memory. The data was acquired to onboard memory previously by the hardware after the acquisition was initiated. member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQAcquisition.Abort
member.summary:
Stops an acquisition previously started with the or
method. You can also use the this method to stop a self-calibration. Calling this method is optional, unless you want to stop an acquisition before it is complete or you are continuously acquiring data.
member.remarks: You can abort reading a power spectrum if it is a triggered acquisition that has not yet been triggered. You can also abort multi-span acquisitions in a middle of a span. If you call this method soon enough, you can abort averaged spectrum acquisitions and single-record spectrum acquisitions.
member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.param: Specifies the first record to retrieve. Record numbers are zero-based. The default value is 0.
Specifies the number of records to fetch.
Specifies the number of samples per record.

param.name: timeout
param.para: NI 5661/5663/5665/5667 - Specifies the time, in seconds, allotted for the function to complete before returning a timeout error.
NI 5644R/5645R/5646R, NI 5668R, NI 5840 - Specifies the time, in seconds, allotted to receive the reference trigger.
param.note: For all supported devices, a value of 1 specifies the function waits until all data is available. A value of 0 specifies the function immediately returns available data.

member.param: Returns the acquired waveform for each record fetched. The waveforms are written sequentially in the array. Allocate an array at least as large as numberOfSamples times numberOfRecords for this parameter

The property was accessed after the associated

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdge.Configure(NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdgeReferenceTriggerSource,System.Double,NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdgeReferenceTriggerSlope,System.Int64)
member.summary: Configures the device to wait for the complex power of the I/Q data to cross the specified threshold to mark a reference point within the record.
member.param: Specifies the source of the RF signal for the power edge reference trigger. The only supported value is "0". Refer to for more information.
Specifies the threshold above or below which the device triggers.
Specifies whether the device detects a positive or negative slope on the trigger signal.
Specifies the number of samples to store for each record that was acquired in the time period immediately before the trigger occurred.

remarks.para: To trigger on burst signals, add a minimum quiet time (configured with property) to ensure the trigger does not occur in the middle of a burst if the acquisition starts while a burst is being generated. The quiet time should be set to a value smaller than the time between bursts, but large enough to ignore power changes within a burst. You can use this trigger with the NI-TClk API.

member.exception:
The method was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.remarks: The device asserts the trigger when the signal crosses the level specified by the value of this property, taking into consideration the specified slope. member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvancedAcquisition.DownconverterCenterFrequency
member.summary: Gets or sets in-band retuning and specifies the current frequency, in hertz (Hz), of the RF downconverter.
member.value:
Specifies a representing the in-band retuning and specifies the current frequency.
Valid values are any supported tuning frequency of the NI-RFSA.

remarks.para: If you set this property, any measurements outside the instantaneous bandwidth of the NI-RFSA are invalid. To disable in-band retuning, reset the property or call the method. After you set this property, the downconverter is locked to that frequency until the value is changed or the property is reset. Locking the downconverter to a fixed value allows frequencies within the instantaneous bandwidth of the converter to be measured with minimal overhead, decreasing tuning time.

member.exception:
The property was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvancedAcquisition.IFOutputFrequency
member.summary: Gets the center frequency of the IF output that corresponds to the configured RF center frequency.
member.value: Returns a representing the center frequency of the IF output that corresponds to the configured RF center frequency.
member.remarks: The downconverter translates RF input frequency to the IF output frequency by mixing it with the LO signal. However, the coarse nature of the LO settings can cause the downconverter to be unable to tune to the exact LO frequency that would produce the nominal IF output. Any coercion in the actual LO frequency results in the IF output frequency being slightly off from the nominal value. Additionally, if you use the and properties to program the downconverter, then the IF output frequency could be very different from the nominal value. NI-RFSA adjusts the acquired spectrum or I/Q data for the difference between nominal and actual IF output frequency. If you use an external digitizer with the NI RF downconverter, use this property to specify the actual IF output frequency.
member.exception:
The property was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

remarks.para: When you set this property, along with the and properties, NI-RFSA calculates appropriate attenuator settings based on the value of this property and the value of the property. In this case, NI-RFSA interprets the reference level as the maximum expected power level of the signal at the input of the external gain device.
With this property set, NI-RFSA reads the property value as the power level at the input of the external gain device at which the NI-RFSA device should trigger.
Negative values indicate attenuation.
For more information about attenuation, refer to the Attenuation and Signal Levels topic for your device in the NI RF Vector Signal Analyzers Help.

member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum corner frequency of the high pass filter in the RF signal path.

remarks.para: Supported Devices: NI 5606

member.value:
Returns a representing the maximum corner frequency of the high pass filter in the RF signal path.
The device uses the highest frequency high-pass filter option below or equal to the value you specify and returns a coerced value. Specifying a value of 0 disables high pass filtering.
Valid values are 0 to 26.5, inclusive. The default value is 0.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvancedSignalPath.LOFrequencyStepSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the step size for tuning the local oscillator (LO) phase-locked loop (PLL).
member.value: Specifies a representing the step size for tuning the local oscillator (LO) phase-locked loop (PLL).

remarks.para: The LO frequency can only be tuned by multiples of the property. The LO frequency can therefore be offset from the requested center frequency by as much as half of the property. This offset is corrected by digitally frequency shifting the property to the value requested in either the property or the property.
When the property is set to , the property can accept any value from 50 kHz to 24 MHz.
When the property is set to , the property is coerced to 4 MHz, 5 MHz, 6 MHz, 12 MHz or 24 MHz.

member.exception:
The property was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvancedSignalPath.AbsoluteDelay
member.summary:
Gets or sets the sub-sample clock delay, in seconds, to apply to the acquired signal. Use this property to reduce the trigger jitter when synchronizing multiple devices with NI-TClk. This property can also help maintain synchronization repeatability by writing the absolute delay value of a previous measurement to the current session. To set this property, the NI-RFSA device must be in the Configuration state.
If this value is set, NI-TClk cannot do any sub-sample clock adjustment.
member.value: Specifies a representing the sub-sample clock delay, in seconds, to apply to the acquired signal. The default value is 0. Valid values are plus or minus half of one sample clock period.
member.exception:
The property was accessed after the associated
object was disposed.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaRFPreamplifierEnabled
member.summary: Specifies whether to enable the RF preamplifier on the downconverter.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaRFPreamplifierEnabled.Disabled
member.summary: Disables the RF preamplifier.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaRFPreamplifierEnabled.EnabledWhenInSignalPath
member.summary: Enables the RF preamplifier when the RF preamplifier is present in the signal path and disables the preamplifier when it is not in the path. Only devices with an RF preamplifier on the downconverter support this option. Use the property to determine whether the downconverter has a preamplifier.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaRFPreamplifierEnabled.Enabled
member.summary: Enables the RF preamplifier. If the RF preamplifier is not in a signal path, NI-RFSA returns an error. Select the option whenever possible to avoid an error.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaRFPreamplifierEnabled.Automatic
member.summary: Automatically enables the RF preamplifier based on the value of the property.
member.value: This value is valid only for the NI 5667.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaChannelCoupling.DC

member.summary: Defines the resolution bandwidth (RBW) in terms of the 6 dB bandwidth of the window specified by the property.

member.summary: Defines the resolution bandwidth (RBW) in terms of the display resolution, which is the ratio of the sampling frequency to the number of samples that you acquire.

member.summary: Defines the resolution bandwidth (RBW) in terms of the equivalent noise bandwidth (ENBW) of the window specified by the property.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode
member.summary: Specifies the averaging mode for the spectrum acquisition.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.None
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device to perform no averaging on acquisitions.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.Rms
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for root-mean-square (RMS) averaging. RMS averaging reduces signal fluctuations but not the noise floor. RMS averaging averages the energy, or power, of the signal. This averaging prevents noise floor reduction and gives averaged RMS quantities of single-channel measurements zero phase. RMS averaging for dual-channel measurements preserves important phase information.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.Vector
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for vector averaging. Vector averaging reduces noise from synchronous signals. Vector averaging computes the average of complex quantities directly, which means that it allows separate averaging for real and imaginary parts. Complex averaging such as vector averaging reduces noise and usually requires a trigger to improve block-to-block phase coherence.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.PeakHold
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for peak-hold averaging. Peak-hold averaging retains the RMS peak levels of the averaged quantities at each frequency bin separately to retain peak RMS levels from one FFT record to the next.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.MinimumHold
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for minimum-hold averaging. The least power in the spectrum at each frequency bin is retained from one acquisition to the next.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.Scalar
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for scalar averaging. The scalar averaging retains the average of the power spectrum.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaSpectrumAveragingMode.Log
member.summary: Configures the NI-RFSA device for logarithmic averaging. The power spectrum is averaged in a logarithmic scale.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType
member.summary: Specifies the time-domain window type.
member.remarks: For more information, refer to NI RF Vector Signal Analyzers Help.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.Uniform
member.summary: No window is applied.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.Hanning
member.summary:
The Hanning window is useful for analyzing transients longer than the time duration of the window, and also for general-purpose applications. A Hanning window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = 0.5 * x[i] * [1 cos(w)] where
w = (2)i / n
n is the waveform size.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.Hamming
member.summary:
A Hamming window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] [0.54 - 0.46 cos(w)]
where
w = (2)i / n
n is the waveform size

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.BlackmanHarris
member.summary:
A Blackman-Harris window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] [0.42323 0.49755 cos(w) + 0.07922 cos(2w)]
where
w = (2)i / n
n is the waveform size

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.ExactBlackman
member.summary:
An Exact Blackman window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] * [a0 a1 cos(w) + a2 cos(2w)]
where
w = (2) i / n
n is the waveform size
a0 = 0.42659
a1 = 0.49656
a2 = 0.076848667

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.Blackman
member.summary:
A Blackman window is useful for analyzing transient signals, and provides similar windowing to Hanning and Hamming windows but adds one additional cosine term to reduce ripple. A Blackman window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] [0.42 0.50 cos(w) + 0.08 cos(2w)]
where
w = (2 )i / n
n is the waveform size

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.FlatTop
member.summary:
The fifth-order Flat Top window has the best amplitude accuracy of all the window methods. The increased amplitude accuracy (0.02 dB for signals exactly between integral cycles) is at the expense of frequency selectivity. The Flat Top window is most useful in accurately measuring the amplitude of single frequency components with little nearby spectral energy in the signal. A fifth-order Flat Top window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] [a0 a1 cos(w) + a2 cos(2w) a3 cos(3w) + a4 cos(4w)]
where
w = (2)i/n
n is the waveform size
a0 = 0.215578948
a1 = 0.41663158
a2 = 0.277263158
a3 = 0.083578947
a4 = 0.006947368

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.FourTermBlackmanHarris
member.summary:
A 4 term Blackman-Harris window is a general purpose window; it has side-lobe rejection in the upper 90 dB, with moderately wide side-lobe. A 4-term Blackman Harris window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] * [0.422323 - 0.49755 cos(w) + 0.07922 cos(2w)]
where w = (2 )i / nn is the waveform size

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.SevenTermBlackmanHarris
member.summary:
A 7 term Blackman-Harris window has the highest dynamic range; it is ideal for signal-to-noise ratio applications. A 7-term Blackman Harris window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] * [a0 - a1 cos(w) + a2 cos(2w) - a3 cos(3w) + a4 cos(4w) - a5 cos(5w) + a6 cos(6w)]
where
w = (2 pi)i/n
n is the waveform size
a0 = 0.27105140069342
a1 = 0.43329793923448
a2 = 0.21812299954311
a3 = 0.06592544638803
a4 = 0.01081174209837
a5 = 0.00077658482522
a6 = 0.00001388721735

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.LowSideLobe
member.summary: The Low Side Lobe window reduces the size of the main lobe.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.Gaussian
member.summary:
A Gaussian window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] * e((-0.5(i - (N -1 ) / 0.5)/((N - 1) / 0.5)) where
N is the length of the window
0.5

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFftWindowType.KaiserBessel
member.summary:
A Kaiser-Bessel window is applied to the waveform using the following equation:
y[i] = x[i] * I0 * (n * a(1 - (2i / (N-1)-1)^2)^0.5)/(I0 * n * a)
where i 0 and i N-1
N is the length of the window
determines the shape of the window
I0 is the zeroth order Modified Bessel function of the first kind

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo
member.summary: Specifies the reference location within the acquired record from which to begin fetching.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo.MostRecentSample
member.summary: Fetching occurs relative to the most recently acquired data. The value of the property must be negative.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo.FirstSample
member.summary: Fetching occurs at the first sample acquired by the device. If the device wraps its buffer, the first sample is no longer available. In this case, NI RF signal analyzer returns an error if the fetch offset is in the overwritten data.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo.ReferenceTrigger
member.summary: Fetching occurs relative to the Reference trigger. This value behaves like , if no Reference trigger is configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo.FirstPretriggerSample
member.summary: Fetching occurs relative to the first pretrigger sample acquired. This value behaves like , if no Reference trigger is configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaFetchRelativeTo.CurrentReadPosition
member.summary: Fetching occurs after the last fetched sample.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvanceTriggerType
member.summary: Specifies whether you want the Advance trigger to be a digital edge or software trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvanceTriggerType.None
member.summary: The trigger is not configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvanceTriggerType.DigitalEdge
member.summary: The trigger is configured to be a digital edge trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaAdvanceTriggerType.SoftwareEdge
member.summary: The trigger is configured to be a software trigger. You can assert the software trigger by calling the method of the .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType
member.summary: Specifies whether you want the Reference trigger to be a digital edge, I/Q power edge, or software trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType.None
member.summary: No reference trigger is configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType.DigitalEdge
member.summary: The Reference trigger is not asserted until a digital edge is detected. The source of the digital edge is specified with the property.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType.IQPowerEdge
member.summary: The Reference trigger is asserted when the signal is changing past the level specified with the slope (rising or falling) configured with the property.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType.SoftwareEdge
member.summary: The Reference trigger is not asserted until a software trigger occurs. You can assert the software trigger by calling the method.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaReferenceTriggerType.IQAnalogEdge
member.summary: The Reference Trigger is asserted when the I or Q signal is changed past the level specified with the slope configured with the property.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdgeReferenceTriggerSlope
member.summary: Specifies whether the device asserts the trigger when the signal power is rising or falling.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdgeReferenceTriggerSlope.Rising
member.summary: The trigger asserts when the signal power is rising.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaIQPowerEdgeReferenceTriggerSlope.Falling
member.summary: The trigger asserts when the signal power is falling.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNISelfCalibrationToneMode
member.summary: Specifies the location in a path where a calibration tone is injected or whether the tone is disabled.
member.remarks: Use instead of this enumeration.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNISelfCalibrationToneMode.Disabled
member.summary: Disables the calibration tone for the associated path.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNISelfCalibrationToneMode.LowbandRF
member.summary: Injects the calibration tone into the low-band RF path.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNISelfCalibrationToneMode.HighbandRF
member.summary: Injects the calibration tone into the high-band RF path. This value currently is not supported.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaNISelfCalibrationToneMode.HighbandIF
member.summary: Injects the calibration tone into the high-band IF path. This value currently is not supported.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaStartTriggerType
member.summary: Specifies constants for different types of Start trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaStartTriggerType.None
member.summary: No trigger is configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaStartTriggerType.DigitalEdge
member.summary: The data operation does not start until a digital edge is detected.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaStartTriggerType.SoftwareEdge
member.summary: The data operation does not start until a software event occurs.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaArmReferenceTriggerType
member.summary: Specifies whether you want the Arm Reference trigger to be digital edge or software trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaArmReferenceTriggerType.None
member.summary: The trigger is not configured.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaArmReferenceTriggerType.DigitalEdge
member.summary: The trigger is configured to be a digital edge trigger.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.ModularInstruments.NIRfsa.RfsaArmReferenceTriggerType.SoftwareEdge
member.summary: The trigger is configured to be a software trigger. You can assert the software trigger by calling the method of the .
